JUDGES: Giovanni Bonello;Ján Šikuta;Lech Garlicki;Mihai Poalelungi;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza
TEXT: The applicants , Mr PERSON and PERSON ( the second applicant ) , are NORP nationals who were born in DATE and DATE respectively and live in PERSON . They were represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , and subsequently by PERSON GPE , lawyers practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , Mr PERSON of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

On DATE the applicants acquired from a third party a plot of land with a surface area of QUANTITY . m ( of which QUANTITY . m was classified as agricultural land ) and a house situated on it located in the municipality of PERSON , settlement ORG . Relevant excerpts from the local development plan were appended to the contract .
According to the relevant local development plan which was adopted on DATE almost the entire property in question was designated for the construction of a ring road .

In DATE or DATE the second applicant ’s health significantly deteriorated . In addition , the applicants’ grandchild had a stroke . Consequently , they decided to sell part of their property in order to pay for the medical treatment of the second applicant and their grandchild . They also wanted to finance their son ’s higher education . However , a number of potential buyers , having learnt about the lack of possibilities to develop the land , lost interest in the property .

On DATE the applicants requested the Mayor of PERSON to clarify whether the ring road would be constructed and informed him about their difficult financial situation and unsuccessful attempts to sell part of their property to pay off their debts .

On DATE the Mayor informed them that the construction of the ring road was not foreseen in the municipality investment plan . He further pointed out that due to the scale of the construction and the character of the ring road , its construction would most likely be financed from the budget of the regional governor or the Government . In those circumstances , the GPE ’s budget could not bear the expenses related to the acquisition of the ORG land .
Subsequently , the applicants made an enquiry with ORG .

On DATE they were informed that the construction of the ring road as part of the regional road no . CARDINAL was still expected ; however , due to limited financial resources no date for that construction had yet been fixed . Furthermore , the applicants were informed that there were no immediate plans to purchase the properties designated in the local development plan for the construction of the ring road . Lastly , ORG requested the Mayor of PERSON to consider providing the applicants with an alternative plot of land .
On DATE , in reply to that latter request , the Mayor informed the applicants that he was unable to offer them an alternative plot of land .

Subsequently , the applicants made a new enquiry with ORG . On DATE they were informed that no date for the construction of the ring road has been fixed , but that it would certainly not be constructed in DATE .

In reply to the applicants’ further query , on DATE the Mayor informed them that their requests for acquisition of their property had been examined by ORG on a few occasions . However , in view of the scope of the planned development of their land ( regional road ) , the GPE could not bear any expenses related to the acquisition of their property .

On DATE the applicants petitioned the ORG . On DATE the ORG informed them that since DATE he had monitored the legal status of properties which , according to the local development plans , had been designated for future public use ; however , they were put to such use only after DATE ( the so - called “ frozen plots ” ) . In particular , he challenged before the ORG section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the DATE LAW which had restricted the ORG possibility to receive compensation for reduction in the value of their properties and to acquire land or to exchange it in cases where the use of property was not feasible or significantly impaired , following the adoption of a local development plan . However , ORG held that the contested provision was compatible with LAW ( case no . K CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . He further informed the applicants that provided that no further statutory extension of the validity of the old development plans was granted , they would be able to have recourse to section DATE LAW .
On DATE ORG informed the Mayor that it was not possible in DATE to finance the purchase of properties designated for the ring road .
On DATE the relevant local development plan expired .
On DATE the applicants requested the Municipality to provide them with information as to the future development of their land .

On DATE they were informed that no local development plan had been adopted in respect of their land . Since the development plan determined the future use of land , no development of the applicants’ property was allowed until such time as the relevant plan was adopted . Furthermore , the applicants were informed that according to the local development plan which was in force until DATE their land was designated for the construction of a regional road .
It appears that as of DATE GPE had not yet adopted a local development plan in respect of the applicants’ land .
From DATE to DATE questions of land development were governed by LAW on ORG .
On DATE the Law of DATE on ORG ( “ the DATE LAW ) entered into force .

Section CARDINAL of the DATE Act provided that in cases where the use of property in the previous manner , in connection with the adoption of a local development plan or its amendment , was no longer feasible or significantly impaired , the owner of such property was to be granted certain rights against the municipality . The owner could either ( CARDINAL ) claim compensation for the damage actually incurred , or ( CARDINAL ) claim that the property be acquired by the municipality , or ( CARDINAL ) that he / she be provided with an alternative property . Section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act was the first provision in the post - war period which provided for some compensatory measures in favour of the owners of properties who were negatively affected by the local development plans . However , section DATE of the CARDINAL Act stipulated that those provisions would be applicable only in respect of those local development plans that were adopted after the Act entered into force ( i.e. DATE ) .

Pursuant to section CARDINAL LAW , the development plans adopted before the date of its entry into force were to expire on DATE at the latest . Subsequently , in DATE and DATE the parliament extended the validity of the old development plans until DATE and DATE respectively .

The DATE Act was repealed by the Law of DATE on ORG ( “ the DATE LAW ) which entered into force on DATE . LAW of LAW stipulated that local development plans adopted before DATE remained valid , but only until DATE .

Section CARDINAL of the DATE Act afforded the owners concerned comparable rights against the municipality to those under LAW in cases where the use of property in the previous manner , in connection with the adoption of a local development plan or its amendment , was no longer feasible or significantly impaired .

In DATE the ORG made an application to ORG , challenging the constitutionality of section DATE read in conjunction with section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act . He alleged that those provisions contravened the constitutional principle of the rule of law , the principle of equality and the right of property . In particular , the ORG challenged the prohibition on filing claims provided by section CARDINAL of the DATE Act in respect of those owners who had been negatively affected by the development plans adopted before DATE .

On DATE ORG dismissed the ORG ’s application . In respect of the alleged breach of the constitutional right of property , ORG considered that the right of property was not absolute , and that in any event the presumption in favour of constitutionality of the impugned provisions had not been rebutted .
